dcterms:creator: M. F. Barnsley
dcterms:description: The Cantor set is a classic example of a fractal, constructed by repeatedly removing the middle third of a segment, resulting in a totally disconnected set.
dcterms:title: Cantor set

dcterms:creator: M. F. Barnsley
dcterms:description: The Sierpinski triangle is a fractal and attractive fixed set with a triangular shape, created by recursively removing triangles from a larger triangle.
dcterms:title: Sierpinski triangle

dcterms:creator: M. F. Barnsley
dcterms:description: The Koch curve is a fractal curve and a classic example of a continuous curve that is nowhere differentiable, constructed by recursively adding triangular 'bumps' to a line segment.
dcterms:title: Koch curve

dcterms:creator: M. F. Barnsley
dcterms:description: Iterated Function Systems (IFS) are a method for constructing fractals; they generate intricate shapes by applying a finite set of contraction mappings iteratively.
dcterms:title: IFS (Iterated Function Systems)
